sp.p: Why, this Damning sinking Person is a lowsie Foot-boy to a more lowsie Brewer, that in former times was coupled with his Masters Horses in grinding the Mault, but since happening into a drunken Aledrinking Parish, has cheated enough to keep his Coach and Six, with a Pox to him!

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: A Foot-boy, udslid, if chad known that, old Crab should ha' walkt about his ears, I'le tell him that.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: If these doings last▪ woe be to all merry Meetings ifaith; why one knows not now who's the Landlord, nor who's the Tenant; which is the King, and which the Cobler. They are both equal now as things are order'd. Well, well, prithee let thee and I walk about our business.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Aye, aye: Let's find the Knight Sir Oliver out, that I may know who I mun pay my Rent to.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Why, are you mad neighbour Slouch: will you pay it to any body, till you zee which is the strongest side.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Nay, by'r Lady, that's almost out of doubt now; for the young Prince that should be King, is banisht: but however I am lawful Tenant to Sir Charles Kinglove.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Lawful! Prithee what's Law against the longest Sword! that'I cut all Law in pieces, and make new ones: don't you see how the ancient▪ Laws are turn'd topsey-turvy, and new ones call the old Kingdom a new Common Wealth.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Why, an' the Law have made it zo, 'tis zo.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Yes while the Protector has 40000 men to back the new Law, and the King none to oppose 'em.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Why neighbour, our Parliament told us, all Soldiers should be Disbanded when the Law was settled; and so we need no more Taxes nor free-quarter, now we have a Law to depend upon.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: How like an Oase dost thee Prate! Why, had not the King Law and Right to depend upon, and yet it would not do against 40000 men.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Well, I say the Law can do any thing.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: But make a Mon a Woman.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: It can make a Mon swear he's a Woman, or hang him.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Yes with the help of Halberteers, and a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: 'Sdiggers neighbour Copyhold, Thou hast a plaguy Noddle! a parlous pate o' thy own; why, thou makest the Law to signifie nothing at this rate: What side should a mon take?

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Take Law's side, whilst 'tis strongest.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: But how shall one know when that is?

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: When't has the 40000 men of its side.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: But if they'r against the Law.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Then be thou against it too, Fool: Had'st not thou rather have 40000 men on thy side against the Law, than the Law of thy side against 40000 men!

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: As the Song says, I perceive Law lyes a bleeding.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Aye, and the Head and Fountain of the Law too.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Swounes, I intended to make a Lawyer of my Son, but I am off on't now.—

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Off on't, why how came that into thy Noddle, what means hast thou?

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Means, Why I breed en' at a Free-School, and if I con raise 40 I. to put 'en to a Torney▪ he may come to be Torney▪General, and make Laws to settle the Crown.—

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Come, come; be rul'd by me Neighbour; my Advice is that you make an Evidence of him, put en to one of the Protector's Plot-makers, and he may come to witnes 'gainst some of the Cavaliers at the High-court of Injustice; and then he's made for ever; and in time may be able to keep his six Servants, or six men for his Life-guard.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Peace, peace, Neighbour; here are Soldiers coming.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.p: Come, come; the times will turn Sirs, we have good news comes every day. The Protector they say is sick, and if the Devil takes him, as I am sure he will; and suddenly, we shall have good dayes again. How now Vermin of the Country, what are you? who are you for Sirrah, the King, or the Commonwealth,—hah?

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Why, an't shall please you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Look! look! He's at his shall please ye. Slouch, be at silence, and let him speak that bears the Brain. Noble Gentlemen, and Fellow Soldiers, to speak affirmatively to the matter, we are for the Commonwealth dee see.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.p: Knock 'em down! swinge 'em, no more words on't, drub 'em confoundedly.—

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: O mercy good Gentlemen! mercy.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p:
Lookee Neighbour Copyhold, I shall desire the favour of you,
that as you bear all the Brain, you will hereafter bear all the beating too: for, for you to be witty, and I to be bruifed for't, zooks I must tell you 'tis a little unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: 'Tis an ill time for Wit in a time of Civil War; for if they had been as ready to break Jests as they are to break heads, I for my Wit had scap'd a Beating, and thou, because a Fool, hadst been beaten more. But for the future, advance and take thy Fortune, and if thou hast any wit I hope thou wilt be Swing'd for't. 'Tis grown a Custom in this Age, and 'twould grieve me if thou should'st miss it.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Here comes more of 'em, now for me; Thou shalt see what a Joke I'le pass upon 'em.

div.stage: Enter Dash, with Soldiers of another Party.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Thomas!

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Go and found me those empty Casks, and try if they are not musty?

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.p: Now Badger of the largest size. Who are you for, Commonwealth, or King? hah?

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Pox o' the Commonwealth; 'tis the very Fundament of Governing; all Tail, and no Head. No, Sir, we are resolv'd to be brave fellows, and for the King, we.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, my brace of rusty Plough shares.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Friends, it behoveth your Discretion to beat them abundantly; Let their Bones be, as it were, broken, and their Flesh bruised: for the feed of Contest is in them, and must be thrashed thence by the Flayle of Reformation.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Gentlemen! I am for the Devil and Money, as you are. I'le be for any thing. A pox o' your Flayle of Reformation.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: A pox o' your Fundament, I say, and your jokes too, if this be the fruit on▪t. You may joke long enough before any one will laugh on your side.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Ill times! barbarous times, as you said, Neighbour. No Wit will pass now, that's the truth on't. How now! who's this? There's no more of 'em coming I hope!

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p:
The Collonel I hear is at liberty, and so is the other witness of my disgrace; therefore without a Plot to invalidate their Evidence, the credit of our Party is ruin'd. A pox on my negligence, and foolish security—I shall raise a scandal on our▪ whole Tribe, by this cursed want of Policy. Well—there is no way but to decoy two or three easie Fools to swear some notorious Crimes against them; by that means to make 'em not be believ'd. Ah! and yonder methinks are two fellows very fit for such a Purpose.
One of 'em I met this morning, leading in his hand a pretty fresh Country wench, and, if I mistake not, he must be a very fit Tool for me to work with.—How now, my honest Country-men, what's the news with you? I warrant your heart akes to see so many Troops of Soldiers abroad, and not a bone about you, but is disorder'd at these War-like Preparations! hah?

sp.speaker: Copyh,
sp.p: Why, faith not to belye our selves, our Bones are a little out of order at present, as you say.

sp.speaker: Slouch
sp.p: Our hearts do ake about the Troopers, indeed. But 'tis because they are not hang'd, an't shall please ye.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: So now has this Fool hedg'd himself into another drubbing by the by.—

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: What, some of 'em have wrong'd you I warrant: In troth I am sorry for't; and you seem to be such honest fellows, that if you will be ruled by me, I will for the future defend you against all such injuries.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Rul'd—aye, with all our hearts good faith.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: This man now has some Conscience in him, but the other were Babylonian Infidels.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: First, What are you? and what's your Business here in Town!

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: We were lately Tenants to Sir Charles Kinglove, and I for my part have born all Offices in our Parish, and kept as good a House, I can take my corporal Oath, as any Farmer in Worcester-shire: Neighbour Slouch there, has kept House too; but I think will knock under the Table if compar'd with mine.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Sir Charles his Tenants! This is as lucky as I could wish.—I see the Devil remembers the good Offices I have done him▪ and will not leave me in distress.—

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: And we are going to find one Sir Oliver Oldcut, to renew our Leases, and know to whom we must pay our Rent.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Sir Oliver Oldcut! why he's my intimate bosome Friend; he does nothing without my advice: But he▪s Sir Charles's mortal Enemy, and if you would oblige him, you must think of Sir Charles. Well, 'tis strange to see some men's Fortune—I am the only person in the world that could do you this good office.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Good Lord!

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: And if you would be trusty and secret, I'de raise ye to a better Fortune than the renewing your Lease. Hark in your Ear, you can swear to a thing upon occasion—umph.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Must the thing be true or false, I pray.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Oh fye, what a question is that in this Age! True or false? why, 'tis all one, 'tis all one, man. If true, there's the more Honour; if false, there's the more Money: 'tis all one, I tell thee. I see, Friend, your neighbor there has no great store of wit.—

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: Wit! hang him Dunce, Dolt, Cuckoo: oons such another word and I'le thrash thee as I would a Sheaf of Barley. 'Sbud Sir, you seem to be so good a Gentleman, that I'le swear any thing for you, and so shall my Wife and Daughter. There's my hand on't.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Nay, nay, hold you; I'le not stand out neither if you go to that.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Follow me then; Be faithful, and be rich. So now will I get Sir Charles and the other Youth apprehended; then baffle their Evidence against me, and by my Wit secure my Reputation. Come my good Friends.

sp.speaker: Copyh.
sp.p: An honest conscientious Gentleman, I warrant him!

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: How is it possible I should think you love me, when you so often suspect my Fidelity.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What have you done! Oh I shall be ruin'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: So far from it, that I have done thee a considerable favour▪ for my Dear 'tis impossible now thou should'st be impos'd upon.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But how shall I get a Husband now! Oh that doubt distracts me: if I had but been marry'd, before you had done this, I had not so much car'd.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I confess the dear pleasure had been so much the safer: but however you need fear no danger, for a Maidenhead is of that obliging quality, that a dull Husband can no more know when his Wife has lost it, by any experiment he can make upon her, than a Gamester can be secure, the set Gold is his own whilst the Dice are throwing: 'tis true, hope and a strong Conceit may do a great deal.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Aye, but we have done more than by strong Conceit certainly.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: We have done nothing but what we should; nay, than what there was absolute necessity for: I could not live without possession of thee, nor could'st thou love me, and not grant me life.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Aye, but the Rules of Vertue, think of that Sir.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: How that quick breath, that tender sigh became thee; thy panting heart sent out its Amorous Summons to bring Loves Champion once more to the Field.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Could we love on virtuously, were we married or so, it were another matter.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Aye, gad that would be a hopeful matter indeed;

Virtuously! why, thy Virtue is involv'd still in thy Love. Love, that like a rich and potent Lord possesses, each close Apartment of this Charming
Body, retains thy Vertue for some fitter season, and therefore shuts it up in some dark Closet, till the Riotous Soul has done its Revelling.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And when it has done, what then Sir?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Then? Why, then Virtue like some Grave Chaplain of a Family, stalks out and Preaches Temperance to the Senses, until another Banquet be ordain'd;

lg.l: And then Virtue, that would against Loves Heav'n rebel,
Envies his Joy, and shrinks into his Cell.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But what if I should be sick, and consequently troubled with a scruple in Conscience?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why then your only way will be to call your Chaplain Virtue out of the Closet, and ask him for a dram of the Bottle.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh fye, well indeed my Dear, you are a very lewd wicked person, sincerely.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Indeed, my Dear, I am a very mild, passionate, constant, modest Fool, sincerely.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay, I must confess you would never talk more than you should do; ah! would you had been as reserv'd in another point.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Rather wish me an Eunuch, faith; 'tis the more obliging Curse, and the only one I wou'd wish the man that is to be thy Husband.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: My Husband! Alas, I shall never have one now.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Yes, a good one, before to morrow night, if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Shall I indeed; who prithee, yourself!

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Me? No, I shall make a better Friend than a Husband a thousand times. I am ready to saint at the name on't, as some are at the sight of a Breast of Mutton. But what think you of Sir Paul Eitherside?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: He's a Fool!

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: The fitter to be a Husband always: your men of Wit will discern your slips of Youth, and are often cross, and ill natur'd.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: To be my Lady Eitherside, a Coach and Six; my Valet, and two Footmen: Well, I swear it may do.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Do? It must do: I know he loves thee to extremity; and let me alone to carry on the Plot, only observe this, that when we are together, you always slight me, and prefer him. 'Twill catch the Goose with less trouble.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I warrant ye, and now I love ye more dearly than ever, for this contrivance to marry me.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And will you always be kind to me?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What! wrong my Husband?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Pish! Prithee no hard words, rather wrong any man than me. Canst thou be so cruel to let me lose thee, to lose the rapting Blessings that waited on the Heav'n of thy Love? No, either swear still to be true to thy Intrigue, or thou shalt never marry I'me resolv'd on't.—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, you are the strangest man: What would you have me do? Marry me first, and wee I talk of these things afterward.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Promise the Earnest of your Love the Wedding-night; which I hope will be to morrow—or—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Pish—well—if I must promise—

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: You must—come then—Married thou shalt be, because I believe 'tis convenient. But I would not lose thee for the world—Hark, there's some body coming—Let's away—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I like the Tune extreamly; Prithee sing it agen.

lg.l: TWa bonny Lads were Sawney and Jockey,
Blith Jockey was lov'd, but Sawney unluckie;
Yet Sawney was tall, well-favour'd and witty,
But Ise in my heart thought Jockey more pretty;
For when he view'd me, su'd me, woo'd me,
Never was Lad so like to undo me;
Fye, I cryed, yet almost died,
Lest Jockey should gang, and come no more to me.
Jockey would Love, but he would not Marry,
And Ise had a dread lest I should miscarry;
For his cunning Tongue with Wit was so guilded,
Tnat I was afraid my heart would have yielded;
Daily he press'd me, bless'd me, kiss'd me,
Lost was the hour methought when he miss'd me;
Crying, denying, and sighing, Ide woo him,
But ah! much ado had I to gang fro him.
But cruel Fate robb'd me of this Iewel,
For Sawney would make him fight in a Duel,
And down in a Dale with Cypress surrounded
Ah! there to his death poor Jockey was wounded;
But when he thrill'd him, fell'd him, kill'd him,
Who can express my grief that beheld him!
Raging, I tore my Hair to bind him,
And vow'd, and swore, I'de ne're stay behind him.

sp.speaker: Crap.
sp.p: The Collonel's come, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Go, make haste and pick those Gilly-flowers, and see the Rosecakes do not burn.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I was conceiting the narrow Wicket of your Garden-door to be the Gate of Paradise; and that I was summon'd hither by an Angel that lov'd me. I hope, Madam, you will exalt the fancy, and not let it fall for want of encouragement.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: That were a way to make you turn Reprobate, and Despair. No, Sir, you shall have Angelical entertainment here: Fair looks, kind words, and a comfortable exhortation.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: So! 'Gad I never had any luck when I touch'd upon any thing of Scripture, it always turns to my disadvantage. An Exhortation. I hope, Madam, you don't intend to make a Saint of me, and treat me with Sacrifice and Pray'r?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: As I am an Angel I must be punctual in my office.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: But thou art an Angel of mortal race, and therefore thy office is different.—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And I warrant you'll say my influence is rather over bodies than souls; but I'll not believe it: And since my Dignity is so Divine, 'tis fit I have decent applause. Come first—What have you to say to my face?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: There's so much perfection in't, that 'tis as impossible for me to commend it justly, as it would be for me to laugh in the midst of the possession of thy love: Thy Beauty being as far beyond all applause, as the raptures of thy enjoyment is beyond all mirth.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.—Well—my Neck!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: The Alabaster Column that supports Wit's Palace.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So—my Breasts!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Two Milky Hills of Joy,

lg.l: Where Cupids lye,
And Lovers dye,
Consum'd in Ecstacy.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What, Rhime too! that could never be extempore, that was stol'n I am sure.—But, come, proceed. My knee—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Your knee! what a Devil, we are not come to the end of the Chapter already, sure? Nay, faith, Madam, I'll have no dodging; for as I have enter'd upon the Text, I am resolv'd to go through with the Sermon: Therefore either give me your Question, or y' Gad I'll proceed without my Cue. 'Sdeath this is just like beginning the first line of a Pray'r, and then crying, Amen.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Sir, from the Forehead to the Breast is known land, which you as well as another may have liberty to treat of: But from the Breast to the Knee is Terra Incognita, and can be discover'd by none but my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p:
Yes, by me, Columbus the second, who knows the land of Canaan to a hair, and affirm its situation to be sub Zona Temperata, the
South-East part of the Globe. And my best way to be sure, is to travel thither. But then, Madam, you must be my Pilot in the Voyage.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My want of skill will throw you on some Rock or other.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I'll bring the Ship off agen, I warrant ye. But, come, this all talking, and no performing, is so like an old crazy couple—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What would you doe? Sure you love me better than to think the open Garden a fit place for any other business.—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: As well as I love you, I find by these Delays you have none for me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Be ungrateful and think so—I know not how to help it.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Will you not revenge me upon your Husband? Did you not promise me?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I did, and will perform it, but cannot this way now; think on some other and try.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: A Pox o' this place; No Alcove, no Cave, no Convenience; nor can I imagine any other way.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Study, your Wit did not use to be Barren; Study some pleasant thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Well—I have it: three things faithfully perform'd—I will have patience—But if fail'd in—without enjoyment 'tis impossible for me to think you love me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come then, Fortune for me: What are they?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: First, I will have thee pull out two of his soundest Teeth, and send 'em to me in a piece of paper. Kneel down and Vow to doe it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I Vow.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Secondly, You must contrive some way or other that I may kiss and embrace you before his face. Vow too, this shall be done.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This too shall be done.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: So: Thirdly and lastly, that I may give him three fair fillups on the Nose; and that he may know it, yet bear it patiently. Vow this too, and I am satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I Vow.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Very well! these things carefully perform'd, I will believe you love me perfectly; and will with patience wait your opportunity for the last dear and only favour.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: They are difficult; but since I have vow'd, I'll do't, whatever happens.

sp.speaker: Crape.
sp.p: Make haste away, Sir, if you love your liberty, for Captain Ionas, yonder, has accus'd you to Sir Oliver for attempting to Fire the City, and the Officers are now searching for you. Your young friend is apprehended for a Rape (Lord bless us!) and is just carrying before Sir Paul Eitherside.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p:
Ah, Damn the Treacherous Villain! The Rogue yesterday
would have brib'd me to Murther him. And now, for fear I should accuse him, has forg'd this Fanatical lye.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come with me, and I'll secure you from the Officers, and find some way to get off your friend. Be constant, Sir, and then you will be gratefull; for though I am fetter'd to this tainted Limb, this Canker of the festring Common-wealth, yet I have Loyal blood within my veins.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Thou must, I know it. Thou soft lovely Creature. Those that have Wit like thee, must needs be Loyal.

lg.l: This Marry'd Lump, this, Husband, is thy shame:
My shame indeed, and Husband but in Name.
And tho in Name I must his Wife appear.
And tho in Name thou must his Wife appear,
Thou art the Mistress of a Cavalier.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT. IV.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir P. Eitherside, Jonas, Oldcutt, Copyhold, Phebe, Aurelia, Camilla, Constable, Officers, with Phillipa Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: IT would be a great stain to my discretion, and I should very much unguild the Jewel of my judgment, if I shou'd not believe the Circumstances of this Rape.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: A Rape! what Villains are these? Your Ear, Sir, by all that's good, 'tis impossible for me to commit a Rape if I would.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Impossible! Ay, that's a fine Wheadle indeed: Impossible! no, Sir, we don't doubt but you are Compos mentis for such a business, as well as a bigger man.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Accept of this, Sir—

lg.l: And afford me but one half hour in private,
And you your self shall own 'tis very impossible.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Half an hour in private! 'Gad I believe this young Rogue has an evil design upon me too: Else why in private with me? I don't like his Leer; He's an Arch-Dog, I warrant him. Let's see what he has given me—hum—Five Guineys—no, it won't do, for Captain Ionas has just now given me Ten.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p:
And, Sir, as I was going to ensnare him according to my promise about your business: The complaint of this Rape was made me by
this honest fellow, and the Villain soon after was seiz'd. The other that we found going to fire a house, has made his escape. But I doubt we shall have him e're long.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: A rare business, I faith—What, Sir, will no less Crimes than Burning our Houses, and Ravishing our Daughters serve your turn—hah, a fine Boy, faith—The Rogue would make an excellent—(what d'ye call him!) What an Eye and Nose is there? Gad 'tis a very fine Boy.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Call in your Evidence there: you are willing to swear all this, my friends.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir,—Ay.

sp.speaker: Cop.
sp.p: We are willing to swear to't, and 't please you, if 'twere as much more.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Ah—ignorant Dogs.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: How, not so, friend, I hope. Give 'em their Oaths, Dash. Captain Ionas, you will swear too about the other business?

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Most zealously, Sir: And with as clear a Conscience, I thank Heav'n, as ever Martyr suffer'd for Religion—

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: I believe ye, faith—And to say truth, these ten Guineys have strengthen'd my belief exceedingly—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Ah, Cursed, Perjur'd Villains: I know 'em now, they were Sir Charles's Tenants. Well, I see I must discover my self at last. There can be no other way.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Stand forth, Sweet-heart, and by the Oath you have taken answer to what shall be demanded.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, Turn up your Hood.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: In the first place, where was this Violence committed?

sp.speaker: Pheb.
sp.p: In the little Parlour, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: In the Parlour! Lord bless us, why, what a shift was there! Why this might have been a Murther, as well as a Rape, all things consider'd.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I have no patience to hear this; Pray, Sir, let me speak.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Pray hear the Accuser, Sir Paul; I think 'tis not fit the Evidence be brow-beaten or disturb'd; for as you were saying, Sir—This might have come to have been a Murther.

sp.speaker: Pheb.
sp.p: Nay indeed, forsooth, I was terribly afraid he would have Murther'd me; for he pull'd a Pistol out of his Pocket, which did so scare me—

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: A Pistol too—why this is worse and worse: And Charg'd with White Powder, I warrant, because it should make no noise.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Turn up your Hood, I say, woman, and turn your face to the Jury.

sp.speaker: Cop.
sp.p: And then he swore bloodily. Phebe, why don't you tell Mr. Justice's Worship what he swore, child?

sp.speaker: Phebe.
sp.p: First he swore Damn him and Confound him, he would have his Will, or—

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Loard bless us!

sp.speaker: Phebe.
sp.p: And then he swore by G, O, D, forsooth; and another new Oath he had by the, by the twelve Postles.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: The Apostles—Mercy on us, what an invention was there? O Tempora! O Mores!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I'll lay my life there's a Trick in this; and that cunning Villain, Ionas, has taught this Wench her lesson.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: There must be something in't by their so often whispering—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Come, come, let him speak: Let's hear what he can say for himself. What a Ruby-lip the young Rogue has too?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I say that this is a Villanous Plot contriv'd against me, and there's not one word true that these have sworn; but 'tis only done in design to invalidate my Evidence against Captain Ionas there, who yesterday wou'd have brib'd the Colonel to have Murther'd ye.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; Alas, weak malice: you'll do well to produce your witness, Sir, and then let the Court judge.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Ah wicked wretch! you know you have disabled me of that; but I have yet one way left to expose thee. Know then, Sir Oliver, that I am—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Hold your peace, Sir: I know what you are well enough: and how dare you, Sir, defame the worthy Captain, hah—he Murther me! He that from his Cradle has held forth against the ungodly.—He, a Villain! Sir, Sir—I must tell you plainly that you are.—'Dsbud, 'tis a fine youth—a smooth-fac'd Rogue; he makes me smile in the very midst of my indignation.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Besides, to make defence ('gainst one that swears for the Protector) without Witness, what a Novice art thou? not to know that 'tis not Truth and Justice that carries a Cause, but substantial Evidence—

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Sir, I think there remains no more, but that you commit him to safe custody, in order to his Tryal.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Let him not out, but upon good Bail, Sir Paul; I would have him secur'd, that I might know where to find the young Dog.
Captain, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: I'll follow you, Sir,—Bravely done, friends, of all hands, and your reward shall be accordingly. But now begon—I'll meet you half an hour hence! Away.

sp.speaker: Pheb.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cop.
sp.p: Come, come, let's begon; I long to be fing'ring the Money.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now▪ Cousen, is your time: you, I am sure, have an interest with him; for 'tis certain the young Gentleman is wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: What shall I doe! I dare not discover my self, lest the Colonel should come to know it: But then to be Imprison'd, is a hated Penance too.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Well, Sir, d'ye consider on your condition? have you ten thousand pound Bail?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Not I, Heav'n knows!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sir Paul,—If I have th' Interest in you, that you have often affirm'd I have, you cannot declare it better than in taking my word for his appearance.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Ah, sweet Madam, sooner than any Alderman's in London: Ay, or than my Lord Mayor's himself, upon my Integrity. Mr. Constable, give him his liberty, and go about your business.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sir, he has committed a Rape.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Ye sawcy Rascal, let him go, I say.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Madam, though this favour be extraordinary, that 'tis impossible I should be gratefull, yet my Innocence shall soon inform you, it is not altogether ill-bestow'd.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: More of that another time, Sir. Sir Paul, this civility has oblig'd me at all times to avow my self your unfeign'd, humble Servant sincerely.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Dear Madam, your words have so pow'rfull an influence upon me, that I fear my breast wants room for the excessive joy; is stuck round with the darts of your Beauty, like an Orange that is stuck with Cloves.

sp.speaker: Crape.
sp.p: Sir Paul, Mr. Alderman Thrum is below, and desires your advice in a Law business; and, Madam, Mr. Heartall privately waits for you in the Drawing-room.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Hush, softly, Fool.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: A pox of his business, and Mr. Alderman too, it could not come in a worse time. Well, dear Saint, I'll but just speak to him, and be with you agen in a moment. 'Gad my Intrigue, I see, goes on rarely—for she's a swinging Fortune, and I believe begins to be desperately in Love with me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Now to my first Love Heartall. What e're becomes of thee, I find I must keep touch with him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Go Crape, and convey this young Gentleman privately to Sir Charles: They must e'en lye together to night, for we can have no convenience for getting 'em away till to morrow. Make haste, and see the Servants be all ready for my design. Away—I think I hear Sir Oliver coming—

And now to my three Injunctions. If I should fail after having so faithfully promis'd, he might have reason to doubt my Wit, as well as my Love. Let me see: First to pull two of his soundest Teeth out: To be kiss'd and embrac'd before his face: And to contrive him a beating, yet keep him patient.—Three fine frolicks indeed to doe to a Husband, for the sake of a Lover. But hang't, he deserves it, and I am resolv'd to try; I used to be lucky at mischief.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O Soul! I have had such sport yonder with the old Alderman—I have so firk't him with Wit; so flaug'd him with stinging Jokes, thou would'st admire, had'st thou heard it. 'Gad I never talk't better since I was a man. My mouth was as full of Wit, as the Sea of Water: And I never spet, but out came a Jest, that put the Table in a greater Roar than there is at Guild-Hall, when one of us is chosen Sheriff.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Yet had less Wit in't than a Speech made to my Lord Mayor, Penn'd by the City Poet, and spoke upon a Pageant.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: A Speech made to my Lord Mayor! 'Gad some of those are notable things, I can tell you that: But as I was saying, we had such laughing: but at what think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: At you.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Me! why how now, you crooked Rib? laugh at me? what at Mr. Chairman? 'Gad I'd have had a Sergeant at Arms at his back, if I had found that. No, Soul, y' are mistaken; you are out, I faith: The main Jest was about my lac'd Cloak.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: About your lac'd Cloak!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ay, and about his saying that Sir Peter Codshead look't more like a Gentleman than I; though I prov'd my Cloak better Lac'd; my Coat better Velvet; my Body better Shap'd, and my Legs fuller in the Calf.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Thrum, and all you mean, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Thrum and all: What, d'ye grow pert, you little Buttock! hah! am I the subject of your Jokes? Come, come hither and kiss me for that, and beg my pardon: Come, Rogue, come, and smite me o're the Lips: Look, I ll stand fair.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Kiss you! not for a Million.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: How! not kiss nown dear Husband for a Million: That's fine, I faith—I'll try that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If you expect I should live an hour after, forbear, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Hey day! what's the Devil in thee? why dost thou turn away thy head so? I am not infectious, am I?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I know not that, Sir: but you are strangely alter'd of late.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Alter'd! 'Tis unknown to me if I am: But how, prithee?

div.stage: Enter Crape, Dash and Footman. A Letter.

sp.speaker: Crap.
sp.p: Now's your time! Carry it cunningly, and my Lady has promis'd to reward you bountifully.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I warrant you; let her not fear me.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Nor me!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: But, Soul! prithee how am I alter'd? in what nature? hah! I long to know what the Devil ails me?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sir, so please you, here is a Letter from Sir Ioseph. Oh—

div.stage: Stands off from him, and turns his head away.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: What, has he got a wry Neck too? Come hither, Sir.
From whom d'ye say—he's gone—what can be the meaning of this? Come you hither, Sirrah.
Hark in your Ear! take this Note and go to my Scrivners, and tell him—
How now, Sirrah; what are you looking on?
Turn your head this way, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: O Lord—I can't! I can't! Ugh, ugh.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: They are bewitch'd sure. Oh, Doll! prithee, dear Doll, run after that Bufflehead, and pull him back agen by the Ears.

sp.speaker: Crape.
sp.p: Oh, fough: This is past all enduring.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: What the Devil ails 'em all? They shun me as a Town-Rook does a Sergeant in Term-time. Soul,—prithee unriddle this Mystery: Are they all mad, or am I? Udsooks, I'm sure I ail nothing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ah, you perceive it not, Sir; and indeed I was loth to tell you, for fear of making you angry. But since it must out, and that like a good Wife, I am oblig'd in Conscience to discover and help your Imperfections. Know, Sir, that you are extremely troubled with a most insufferable, nauseous, abominable, stinking Breath.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: A stinking Breath!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Most Pestilential Sir! enough to breed distempers in a family. It must of necessity be occasion'd by some ill Teeth. Pray open your mouth, Sir—Ay, 'tis so—I see 'em now.—Look, Crape—Oh monstrous: they are as black as Ink.

sp.speaker: Crap.
sp.p: Ay, or Charcoal, upon my honesty, Sir: Get 'em pull'd out quickly, or you are undone.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Let it be done immediately. Delay not a minute longer. Why, it is enough, Sir, to poison all your Wit, and utterly ruine all your excellent Discourse of State-policy.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: How! poison my Wit: Run Crape! run and call a Surgeon instantly: 'Gad I'll not leave a Tooth in my head, rather than the least grain of my Wit should be damnify'd: Run, run Crape; Ugh, ugh—I think I begin to find it my self now.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Bid the Surgeon pull out two of the soundest, and be sure to bring two hollow Teeth with him, to have ready, if he should ask to see 'em.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: I have observ'd that this imperfection is very natural to a Statesman. An Orator sooner gets it than any other man; for I remember, I my self have often turn'd my Ear to hear a famous Politician of this Age speak, when it was impossible for me to turn my face to him.—Oh, are you come, Sir; that's well.
Why! here it seems I am like to be poison'd by a damn'd confounded couple of Teeth. Pray look, d'ye see 'em?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: See 'em! Ay, Sir▪ too plain: Stop, stop your breath, I beseech you, Sir,—Ods so—'tis well you sent for me in time: Pray, Sir, stop your breath.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Stop my breath—What a pox, would the fellow have me choak my self? Are they then so dangerous, do you say?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Dangerous, Sir! I assure you, if the Acrimonious quality of this Aqueous malignity had dilated it self through the nervous parts belonging to the Dentes or Teeth, upon the Thorax or Jugular Vein, the Virulity or sharpness of it had doubtless infected, or, as a man may say, penetrated—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Or as a man may doe as well as say. A pox, Sir, I am not at leasure to hear out your Dispensatory at this time; prithee let thy Tongue wag no more till my Teeth are out, and then—

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Well, Sir, well, I stand corrected—Sit still, I beseech you, and open your mouth.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Be sure you take care of my Tongue; I wou'd not have that pinch'd for a 1000 l.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Good Sir, be patient, I warrant you.

div.stage: Pulls it out and shews it.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Oh, the Devil go with it; is it gone?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Gone—Ay, you need not fear, Sir,—I am Master of my faculty—D'ye see, Sir? was this fit to stick in the Jaws of a Politician?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ods-heart—it looks like the Tooth of a Camel, rather than a Politician—Come, come, out with t'other—quickly—I am impatient; 'Tis, 'tis gone: 'Gad if all the Committee had such Grinders, we should have a great many very unsavory Votes amongst us—Come, come—aw—

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Shut your Eyes, Sir, and turn your Fauces or Jaw-bone towards the North-East.—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: The North-East! Prithee which is the North-East? 'Sbud how dost thou think 'tis possible a man should know the points of the Compass that has such Teeth in's head.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: There, there, Sir, to that Corner: Wink, Sir, pray wink.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Prithee make haste, and out with't.
I am to meet the Cabal to night at the Coffee-house about earnest business.—Oh, oh my Jaws are torn in pieces.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Pshaw, pshaw, you must have patience, Sir, 'tis not yet out.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: It only hangs by a piece of skin, I can pull't out now my self—Hah—what's here? Ods-heart, the soundest Tooth in my head—Oh, Dog, Villain, Son of a Whore—I am ruin'd, spoil'd, undone, doom'd never to bite any thing harder than a Custard henceforward: Stand, stand out of my way—I'll Murther him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Bid the fellow begon, Crape.
How, my Dear, has the Rascal mistaken and drawn a sound Tooth?—Prithee—let's see't.—

sp.speaker: Crape.
sp.p: How, a sound Tooth! now out upon him for a blind Villain.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Stand away, I say, and let me come to him; I'll not leave a bone of him unbroken as big as a Capon's leg—Oh damn'd Son of a Whore—a sound Tooth—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; this was rarely perform'd, and one of my great injunctions is prosperously concluded. But now if the Surgeon should play false, through fear, and discover the trick; to prevent that, run Crape, and give him his reward—for money is as great an incouragement to a mercenary fool, as a beautifull Mistress is to a man of Wit. There's no danger to be fear'd, where there's such recompence. Away, there's some body coming.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Was he so very fond, say'st thou, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh, to admiration; took my Bail for the Gentleman's appearance at first word; and was so carefull to be Rhetorical and Florid, as if his life lay upon't, or his preferment sincerely.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Nay, the snare is so well laid, the Woodcock must of necessity be caught.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And can you say we do not live in a very wicked age, where it is counted so insufferable a piece of folly to Marry.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: No, faith, not when we are so lucky to have the good effects of Marriage without it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Fy, you should be more generous than to insult.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: You, methinks, should be more kind than to call this a wicked age, only for being passionate and obliging; nay, only for giving you a brisk taste of a Vessel of excellent Wine, when otherwise you might be condemn'd to the Droppings of the Matrimonial Tap, as pall'd and insipid as a Vintner's Tub full of dead Wine and Flies.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And is not this a sort of vanity? Nay, now I see it is not in your power to forbear insulting, for you Men always love the Triumph above the Conquest. Oh, what a malicious pleasure you take to enjoy her for a Mistress, that you another—as a Virgin for a Bride.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: Why, faith, I confess there is a kind of a Tickling in't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And then to boast of it at the Tavern to one of your friends—as thus—Ah, Iack—I have the pretty'st Rogue to my Mistress, so soft—so kind, and not above 18 at furthest: I lay with her all last night, you Dog—(A pox, some damn'd bulking Whore or other, says he.) A Whore cry you agen, Damme, a Person of Quality's daughter—I have been intimate with her these two years, and design now to Marry her off to one of my friends—because I fear the poor Rogue is breeding.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha; Faith I'll kiss thee for this, and will own some such foolish vanity we men have; but 'tis with security, for we always take care of Names and Places. But hark—I think I hear Sir Paul coming: now to our set Carriage: I with my Hat off, thus cringing;
and as sneaking and demure as the picture of a Whining Lover before a Novel.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And I as full of ridiculous scorn, as a Court-Lady that mistakes pride and ill-breeding for becoming state and grandeur, that has the ambition to be admir'd by every one, yet by her ill carriage gives every one occasion to hate her.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Hist! he comes—
This is a cruelty, Madam, I little expected from you—

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Sirrah, tell their Worships I▪ll meet 'em at the Coffee-house presently.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I think I gave you little encouragement: Pray forbear this discourse, Sir; indeed you are strangely troublesome—

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I love you faithfully.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Y' are the more unlucky, in my opinion: Dear, Sir Paul, your entire Servant. Lord, I have been so plagu'd with Impertinencies since you went.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Say you so, Madam: What had I best do now?—Draw, Sir▪ Methinks every Gentleman should have Wit enough to know when his discourse to a Lady is gratefull. Lord! how the poor fellow looks?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—I shall know when to speak: and to you, Sir, for whose sake I perceive I am thus slighted.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come, Sir Paul, I have some rarities in my Closet; Pray lend me your hand a little.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Well—I shall find an hour.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Find an hour, Sir!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, Dear, Sir Paul, don't mind him, I warrant he mistakes me for his Landladies Maid or his Sempstress.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: 'Gad if he threatens me agen, I'll take the Law of him; I know how to deal with such Tories as himself; I'll hoist him into Westminster-Hall with a wet finger, and so drill him from Court to Court, till he's as poor as a Church-Mouse, or an honest Attorney.

sp.speaker: Heart. Sol.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—give you, Sir,—give you joy. Well, I think I have by this business a little expos'd the humour of the times, and shown what uncertain Merchandize a Woman is, and what luck all young Traders in Love are liable to—But by the way of instruction to my Brethren; were I to begin the World agen—I should sooner suspect an affected coyness, than a careless gaiety; for a Crackt Virgin is as certainly known by her scornfull look, and over-acted modesty as a private Bawd is by her Lozenges and Practice of Piety. Well—if things hit luckily, I shall meet her to morrow night, till when I leave her to her Coxcomb,—How now, what's the matter?

div.stage:
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
Enter Phillipa, running cross the Stage with her Breeches in her hand.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh, I am undone! lost! ruin'd! whither shall I fly?

div.stage: Enter Sir Charles in his Night-Gown, with a Light.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, I am resolv'd to know who thou art, though I follow thee to Sir Oliver's bed-side—Hah—who's this? what, Ned?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Sir Charles, is't possible? Sure this house is Faiery-land. Why how in the Name of Wonder came you hither? and what Nun is that you have made doe such Pennance?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: When I've overtaken her, thou shalt know more; till when, farewell—

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: What c • n this mean? and how does he dare to venture thus into the house of his enemy? nay, and like an eager Falcon, Chase his Quarry, even into the very snare of the Fowler. 'Tis very strange; and if my Mistress were not secure with her Fool in the Closet, I shou'd be damnably suspicious of a Counter-Intrigue: but since that's impossible, I am the less disquieted. Oh—here they come agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: This is the oddest adventure, Ned, I ever met with—my little friend here; my Companion, Phillip, by being this night my Bed-fellow, I have found to be a Woman.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: A Woman by this light, or else I have lost one of my senses.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; this is the strangest chance: but, prithee, how came the discovery?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why, Sir, by the help of an especial friend we were secur'd here to night from the Officers and Sir Oliver; and being forc'd to make shift with one bed, we lay together, when a little while since my Bedfellow being fast asleep. I had the good fortune to know my mistake, and found in my arms a young Beautifull Woman, with little round swelling Breasts, white and fragrant Bosom; and, in fine, all things thereunto belonging and appertaining.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Faith, y' are a very lucky man, Sir; for my part, I cou'd never meet with these surprizing blessings.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Sir, if ever you would oblige a poor unhappy creature, that never meant you any wrong. I beg you to let me go without making any further discovery.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Oh, to doe that, is impossible for me.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: When you know me, I fear you'll hate me, and discard me your presence for ever; which (if you doe) I am sure will break my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Thou canst not think me sure so barb'rous: What▪ my dear friend, the faithfull Partner of all my troubles, that in my greatest necessity supply'd my wants—no—I shall love thee better now than ever.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh, if I were but sure of this!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Thou art; let this confirm it. Come, speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Since then it must be known, my Name, Sir, is Phillipa—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: D' ye start—Nay, then my fears increase, and I am agen undone.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Phillipa, what that beauteous Virgin that so much did love me; who, though an Heiress, left a mighty Fortune to spend her days in discontented Travel.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: The very same, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir har.
sp.p: Phillipa, that disguis'd at Worcester Fight, so nearly lost her life for me, that since in all my miseries kept by me, she that I slighted for her Father's sake; and because he was a Rebel, scorn'd and laught at.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: She, Sir, the poor unhappy she.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I think I have some Loyalty; yet I shou'd no more have lost the possession of such a beauty, because her Father was a Rebel; than I shou'd desert the Mansion-house of my family, because my Father dy'd there.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I conjure you, Sir, by your Loyalty, and that I know is sacred; be not angry with me; let me not lose you quite, though you cannot love me; all my Estate is yours; I freely give it: so is my heart the dearest faithfull Closet of your Merit. Look not then on me as my Father's daughter, but a poor Maid that lov'd, and was unhappy.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Let my arms seize my heart's divinest Joy, or it will break its Breast to meet the blessing. But think not, dearest, of my life, thy wealth could charge me thus? No, that is far below me; and thou art moulded with so many Vertues; so many splendid Graces shine about thee, that to desert thee, were the worst of follies: besides, whatever thy Father was, thou art for the King, I am sure: Hah, art thou not?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Yes from my Soul.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Then thou art mine for ever.
The rest of thy story—I'll hear within, when thou art warmer cloath'd. Come, Ned, thou shalt go with us—for I believe there's no getting out for thee to night.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir: by this means I shall see my Mistress the sooner.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I hope they are all asleep, and have not heard us—Come my be • t life.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: This was beyond my hopes.—

div.head: SCENE. A Coffee-house.
div.stage: Eitherside and several Men sitting smoaking at one Table, and Oldcutt and Jonas seeming to be earnestly in dispute at another, &c.
Enter Coppyhold, Slouch in Tawdry fine Clothes.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: I have often wonder'd how a great many of these Sparks of the Town liv'd so high, and went so fine: but I find now it may be done without a miracle; for if they are owners of a good, tough, durable Conscience, and can but be ingenious, 'tis evident there are such fine toys to be had, as fine Clothes and Money.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Ay, there are such Toys as Halters to be had too; I wish we are not forc'd to play with them at last.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Halters! ay, prithee keep them to thy self like a shallow brain'd fool as thou art; the word is much too low for my imagination; for I intend to swear on till I am a Person of Quality, and then I know my fate will be different.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: Nay, we are pretty well dip't now; we are over boots, thanks to our Stars, and may as well go forward now as be trapt, and so forc'd to swear back agen. But prithee what were those two that we saw hooted through the streets just now? Romans do they call 'em?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Romans! no, nor Apostles neither, Fool: Why, what an Ignoramus is this! he has no more wit now in his new Clothes, than he had in his old Gray Jacket that he follow'd the Plough with: They were two men suspected to be Priests, fool; and, faith, deserv'd the disgrace for ordering their business no better; had I been in their cases, I wou'd have got preferment instead of a punishment; I would in a short time have risen to have been a Holy Fryer after the Order of St. Dominick.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: And so be Hang'd, Drawn and Quarter'd after the Order of the House of Commons.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Not a word more of Hanging, lest I prophecy on thy Fate.—See, yonders the Captain and the Cabal; let's go and sit down.

div.stage: Enter Lieutenant Broom and a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Coffee-Boy.
sp.p: Coffee or Tea. Gentlemen, d'ye want any Coffee?

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: This Coffee house is the Epitome of Hell, where all sorts of male-contented Fiends are in office. Dost thou see that fellow, Ned, there in the Plush-Jacket?

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: That shakes his Noddle so?

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: The same; that Rogue was one of the Committee of Abjuration, and without doubt is now speaking Treason to the Rascal that sits over against him.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: For heav'ns sake what's he with the Spectacles?

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Why, faith, I think, if it be possible, a worse Villain than t'other. One Sir Timothy Tiburn, that had an Estate given him by the last King of sacred Memory, sold it lately to raise Forces to fight against this. Prithee look on 'em; Didst thou ever see such a stigmatiz'd Crew?

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: 'Tis ever so, your Coffee-house, I have observ'd the Mart of the Mobile, and throng'd by people of all sorts and qualities, where your Mechanick may vent Sedition at an easie rate, and look as big as your Alderman or Grandee.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Let's sit down and observe.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Hum; what's here? Order'd that a Bill be brought in for Naturalizing, and this Question be debated, Whether a Presbyterian Dog's Son may not Marry an Independent Bitches Daughter, they being Brother and Sisters Children. Why, what a mad Quaere is this—Ha—and here agen. Resolv'd by the Reverend the Judges of the Law, that it shall be present Death for any Phanatick to hang himself.—Tear it, tear it—don't let it be seen.—Tear it, I say.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: How, Sir! Five hundred Jesuits do you say?

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: More, Sir; near Six hundred, with Monks, Secular Priests and others.

sp.speaker: 1 Comit.
sp.p: And found in a Cave in a Garden at Lambeth?

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: So the Intelligence says, Sir; and you know that can't lye: Besides, upon occasion I can bring those will swear it.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: If he should bring us in agen now for this, 'twere fine.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Peace, Fool: why if he shou'd, we must do't.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what is suppos'd to be their design?

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Why, Sir, as I am credibly inform'd, their design was to dig a way under the Thames to White-Hall.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Under the Thames, Sir!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ownds, Treason—I smell Powder—A second Powder-Plot—The whole State's in danger. Under the Thames! why who the Devil wou'd have thought it had bin possible?

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.p: This Plot was hatcht in Rome, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: These are rare Rogues now.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: This lye well spread, is enough to raise a Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: And you say, Sir, there are several will affirm this to be true.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: A great many, Sir; go but to Toby Papscull, at the Sign of the Rams-horn, over against the Pillory in Cornhill, and you have it printed under their hands. Hold, I think I have a List of their Names in my Pocket. Oh here 'tis.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Hah, and I profess all worthy Persons—I know 'em intimately. Let me see—here's Ieremy Rakehell, Sir Iohn Bullyrock, Iohn Greasy and Sawny Scrubham; all good men and true.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Who is that▪ Rakehell, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ieremy Rakehell—why, Sir,—he's a Counsellor at Law.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: A very ingenious fellow; I faith, and has the best way of forging deeds, and picking up Evidence of any in the Inns of Courts▪—Oh, the Rakehells were all great Lawyers, and ever strong supporters of our Cause.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: I believe no less, Sir. But, Sir Iohn Bullyrock, what's he?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: He; why he's a pushing Captain, that will fight any thing under the Sun upon any Cause, without fear, wit, conscience or honesty. Oliver Knighted him for breaking his head at a Match at Foot-ball.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: The Bullyrocks were ever brave fellows: the Protector himself was a Bullyrock by the Mothers side.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Ay, and a Villain by the Fathers.—Well, Sir, the next.—What's that Iohn Greazy?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Iohn Greazy; why, faith, a notable fellow too. A Tallow-Chandler, that formerly kept a Melting-house, next door to Doctor Cluttergoods, the great Orthodox Minister, and politickly plac'd there by our party with design to stink the Doctor out of the Parish.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: A very excellent design, I faith, Sir.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Yes, and deserves only hanging: But who's this last, Sawny Scrubham? that's a name I never yet heard of.

sp.speaker: Old,
sp.p: Why, Sir, he's a red-hair'd Scotchman, that will engage upon his honour to give the Itch to a whole Army; and to that degree, that in a short time they shall scratch themselves to Death: A very necessary fellow, faith, and will be employ'd suddenly upon a great design.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: He will so.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; the Rascals make me laugh at what I hate.

div.stage: Eitherside and a Tailer at another Table, quarrelling about State-politicks.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Sir, you are an impertinent fellow to pretend to talk about State-affairs.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir, I know what I say, and will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: You pretend to talk of Chronology, and of Genealogy, of the policies of Princes, and of the King of France. Come, what is the King of France? whose Son was he?

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: The Son of his Father, Sir, otherwise call'd Lewis the 13th, and Grandchild of Henry Burbon, surnamed the Great: He's one that keeps a standing Army of a 100000 Men; and I suppose will firk us, if we have not more care.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: He firk us, 'Gad we have 400 Men in little England, that will snap him up as a Crow does an Oyster.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: They must open their Purses a little more then.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Sir, the Land is rich, and flourishes in security, and that 'tis good policy to keep a standing Army—I say 'tis nonsense.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: Ask the Protector that, and hear what he says: Ah, wou'd I might advise.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: You advise! why, what are you, Sir, if you go to that, that you wou'd advise?

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Man as well as you, though my Profession be but mean.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Why, what's your Profession, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: What I am not asham'd of Sir: I am a Womans Tailer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: A Tailer, Sir, and talk of Politicks! 'Gad thou deserv'st to be run through the Guts with thy own Bodkin. A Tailer! Sirrah, mind your business, and Pad my crooked Ladies Gown on the right side, that her Bunch may not be seen—But never exercise your Needle in stiching the Commonwealth, you Rascal.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: Sir, this place is free for any one, and I'll have my penyworth of Politicks as well as the best of you. I know no reason why a Tailer shou'd not have the privilege to talk Treason as well as a Knight.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Sirrah, I am a Justice of Peace, and a Counsellor at Law; and you are an Impudent fellow to contend with a man of my Honour and Authority.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: Sir, I have bin Scavenger, and am now a Constable, and care not this for your Honour and Authority.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Sirrah, I will chastise thee with this Mug.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: If you do, I shall shew▪ you Moorfields play.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: How, Sirrah; I'll try that.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Hold, Valiant Knight and Tailer, cool your Choller: No bloodshed, I beseech you; I'm come to qualifie the business and divert you: I'll shew you a new Satyr.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: A Lowzy shred, an empty Pin-cushion and affront me: 'Gad I'd have eaten the Rogue up, but that I was afraid his Thimble and Sheers wou'd stick in's Throat.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: No more, Sir, I beseech you; he's penitent; and pray have patience and hear this▪ 'tis a new Song, was given me this morning—I'll Sing it you—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well, come, prithee let's hear it.—

lg.l: NOw, now the Tories all must droop,
Religion and the Laws,
And Whiggs of Commonwealth get up
To Tap the Good Old Cause:
Tantivy-Boys must all go down,
And haughty Monarchy;
The Leather Cap must brave the Crown,

l.hi: And Hey then up go We.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The Name of Lord shall be Abhorr'd,
For every Man's a Brother;
What Reason then in Church or State
One Man should Rule another?
When we have Pill'd and Plunder'd all,
And Levell'd each Degree,
Wee'l make their plump young Daughters fall,

l.hi: And Hey then up go We.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Wee'l down with all the Versities,
Where Learning is profest,
Because they Practise and Maintain
The Language of the Beast:
Wee'l Exercise within the Groves,
And Teach beneath a Tree;
Wee'l make a Pulpit of a Cask,

l.hi: And Hey then up go We.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: What thô the King and Parliament
Do not accord together,
We have most cause to be content;
This is our Sun-shine weather:
For if good Reason should take place,
And they should once agree,
'Dzowns who'd be in a Round-head's Case,

l.hi: For Hey then up go We.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Wee'l break the Windows which the Where
Of Babylon has Painted;
And when the Bishops are run down,
Our Deacons shall be Sainted.
Thus having quite Enslav'd the Town,
Pretending 'tis too free;
At last the Gallows claims her own,

l.hi: And Hey then up go We.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Ha, what think you?

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: That you shall be beaten abundantly: Down with him, friends.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: There goes more to the beating a Soldier than you imagine—Have at you.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE I. An Orchard.
div.stage: Enter Sir Charles K. Heartall, Phillipa.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: NOw all my Joys are Crown'd, and nothing but the Bond, the sacred Bond of Marriage can have power to make addition to my Blessings; which shall be done, and suddenly.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: When you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Three days shall be the utmost time; till when, Madam, let me desire you to keep this garb, and not discover your self to any one, till what I have design'd comes to perfection.—I have had secret Intelligence of this perjur'd Rascal, this Villain that swore the Rape against thee, and intend now to expose him.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: That was a precious Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I have bin with Council about it, and will by Proxy get him apprehended; till when, my dear, let no one know your sex or quality, lest it should prevent proceedings.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I am forewarn'd, Sir, and will in every thing obey you.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Thou kindest, dearest of thy sex—how am I bound to thee! thou, that like the Darling Genius of the Heav'ns, consign'd by Divine Power to reward Vertue too generously, hast repaid Ingratitude with heaps of dazling Gold, and much more dazling Beauty.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Forty thousand pound and a pretty Lady: 'Gad 'twould make me distracted—I should do nothing all day long, but tell my money, and kiss my wife, and then be most insufferable insolent: but what would make another man proud, I find makes you asham'd; which, faith, I think is the meaner folly of the two, though it be more gratefull.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: However, of the two evils, I'm sure 'tis the best, though, I confess, Ned, very unfit for thy constitution; for thou, like a factious Statesman, would'st be no more contented with a mean folly, than with a mean estate; so that the consequence might be dang'rous, therefore 'tis high time for thee to grow wise. But who comes here?
What, my man of mickle might! 'Tis Spring always when Nightingales appear. How dost▪ thou, Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: Noble Colonel, much the better to see you well; why, faith, I have bin scowring your Coffee▪ house yonder; I have chastiz'd some of the factious Rogues for you—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And prithee in what old stump or hollow Tree? hast thou liv'd like a Cuckow since we parted—hah.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: What news from our great Master and the Royal Party?

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: The good news I hear is, that the Protector lyes a dying.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: 'Twould be better news if he were hang'd.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: And we are all in hopes to see good days agen; my ill news is, that the King wanting a Hundred thousand pounds, can by his Loyal Party be supply'd but with Fourscore; so that he is in extream distress for the other Twenty to dispatch an extraordinary affair. Ah; Colonel, did you flourish as formerly? I know you would be the first to offer this.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: So will I now the first. And thus low bend my knee—with thanks to the Divine Powers for giving me ability. Now my best Love, show thy self all Divine; show the sordid World how thy Celestial soul surmounts 'em in an unequall'd Generosity; thou freely gav'st me Wealth, give me then leave as freely to dispose it to this great advantage, and lay it at my gracious Monarch's feet.—Doe this, and with a noble freedom doe it; and all the dearest motions of my soul are thine eternally, as firm and constant as the Centre is to the Earth, or the Sun to Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Sir, I have done it already; and now I hope you'll think me a Royalist.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hast thou? that was an Angel's voice, and Millions of Blessings Crown thee for the Deed. Oh my best Love, how can I e're requite thee?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I heard the news yesterday, and did it with the greatest haste and secrecy imaginable.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: A thousand thanks to the most gen'rous of her sex: And once more humbly thus I thank the Heav'ns for giving me this means to serve my Prince. Oh, did he want as many drops of blood from the dear Centre of my life, my heart, as he does pounds from my now happy store, should it not freely bleed? Strong in my zeal beyond Mortality, with my own hands I'd crush the trembling Lump, untill the Noble Loyal Debt was paid.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: But hark you, friend, laying these whimsical Transports aside; Are you mad? what security do you expect for this money?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: None, Sir, nor desire it: The Honour I shall gain outweighs all Interest.—

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ay, and yet this is so damn'd an Age, that there's very few are ambitious of that honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p:
Security: Wer't thou not a Fool, whom I sometimes call my Friend—I would quarrel with thee for that question▪ Why thou moderate
Coxcomb, thou Time-server, would'st thou have me deal with my King as with a Scrivener, or change the Royal favour of his Countenance for a bargain and sale like a Plebeian? No, 'tis my glory; I am a friend to the Nation, in being so to him; Who loves the King, must love his Honour, Grandeur and Prerogative▪ His Regal State, which Money must support.—'Tis the Nation's Honour and Magnificence, a noble and becoming Royalty: And he that dares be so, abhorr'd a thing so wretched, lost in all discerning eyes to see his Monarch want in such a juncture, such a time as this; yet be so basely poor, to hoard up Wealth: His very Soul is dirt, and should be swept hence with the Common Rubbish of the World.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: But 'tis fit the Subject be repaid▪ Colonel.

lg.l: A Loyal Subject thinks himself repaid
By purchasing his Country Peace and Honour;
The only just return a King shou'd make▪
Who cannot pay each Subject as he would:
The zealous Ancients sacrific'd to Heav'n,
Rais'd Altars, built rich Temples to the Deity;
Yet who e're knew the Sacred Pow'r return
One Peny back, but only in effects,
In show'ring gratefull blessings for their Zeal;
And so the King does daily pay his People.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: To you now this is plain; but there are a sort of men in this Age, that say they can see better.

lg.l: They lye—
Your factious busie Coxcombs never see;
Their treacherous fear still makes the object double:
Double their meanings are; their Actions double;
And more than ten times double their false Hearts:
These are the Rogues that look on Government
With as false eyes as thoughts; and gape for Rebellion
As stranded Fishes the return o'th' Wave,
That wafts 'em back to their own Element.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: This plain dealing will hardly get your estate agen; Sir Charles; and for my part, I should be very loth to see such honesty as yours ill rewarded.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Honesty; Ned, in this Age, is a very scarce commodity, because 'tis woven with Loyalty▪ and true Loyalty▪ expects no reward; for that,

lg.l: Like Charity to the Poor,
Is repaid from th' Eternal Store.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I think so, for the Devil a peny it will have from Earthy Coffe • as times go.

lg.l: Yet that I have a little Honesty▪
I know, because I ever hated Flattery;
I cannot bow the supple head and knee
To an unthinking heap of Wealth and Honour:
Nor tell the gaudy Rebel he does politickly,
To side with th' Factious City 'gainst the King.
I cannot Count'nance a wrong Title to be preferr'd.
Nor shake my head, nor rail at the ill Times,
When I am Conscious, I am one that makes 'em so.
I cannot Lye for Honour, Pimp for Profit,
Plot for Salvation, nor Preath up Commonwealths;
And therefore in my Conscience I am honest.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Faith—I believe it; and what e're I have said, was only to extract this Quintessence; this brave opinion from you. And so dear Colonel, your humble Servant; I have a little business, and must beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Your time's your own, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Now to Aurelia—I hope by this she's marry'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I am very glad he's gone, for he might else have hindred my assignation with Camilla, who appointed me here in this Orchard to come and take my second revenge upon her Husband, which is to kiss and embrace her before his face: The Scene must needs be pleasant, and therefore I'll not miss it: I think 'tis now the time; and see the punctual fair one comes just to my wish.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I have bin plotting for you; and though 'tis a difficult business, yet to me you shall find all things are easie.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: If all things are so easie as you say, Madam, you may oblige me, and change this for another favour that I shall name; Faith 'twill be all one now your hand is in.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, Sir, you are so dang'rous in your proposals, that I'll stick to my first Injunction: Therefore begon to your Post behind you bush—lest he come and surprize you.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: If he does, hee'l only think I came to rob the Orchard.—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Hee'l make a shift to guess another sort of Felony.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: What's the Sign?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: And then invade the Province—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Dash,—you are sure you have your lesson right?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: As you could wish, I beseech you, doubt me not.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: There's your reward▪ Be ready then I think I hear him coming—
Dash—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: So please your Honour—I attend.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Get up into this Tree, and fetch me some of those Pears.

div.stage: Dash gets up into the Tree.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Oh, Soul! here has bin plaguey news within; damnable stratagems since you left us; my damn'd Captain Ionas has bin found by the Constable and Officers in bed with a Whore; and what's more strange, is accus'd and apprehended for hiring a fellow to murther me—Bless us, who would have thought a fellow should smile in one's face, yet have such a Villainous design—'Gad I always took him to be as honest as the best of us—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And I too I assure you, Sir: But pray who has accus'd him?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Counsellor Quibble, I hear, and some others that have found out his haunts: there's a whole Nest of 'em discover'd, and they are now Examining before the Committee.

sp.speaker: Dash
sp.p: Fy, fy, Madam, what, this Indecency in an open Orchard? Sir Oliver; Master—Madam I say, for shame expose not your selves thus in open view; have but patience till I can get down, and I'll retire and leave you alone.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Leave us alone! what a Devil does the fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: He's bewitcht I believe.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What, not yet? why, Sir Oliver? Madam, the Servants will come and ketch you—Fy, 'tis a shame such things as these should be done so publickly.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: What things, Dunce! what things! the Devil's in the fellow, sure.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And his Dam too, I think.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No Shame, no Decorum, no Modesty—Well, I am resolv'd I'll be no witness of this Slander to the Brethren; I'll leave you to your selves, and then doe what you will—Hah—bless me, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: What▪ art thou mad? what modesty? what Decorum should be us'd more than there is? hah?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Or what have we done that is a Slander to the Brethren?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What delusions have infatuated me? I do profess, if they be true, and you have continued in this posture: The Pear-tree is inchanted.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: What, the Pear-tree inchanted?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I confess I have heard so, but never could give credit to't.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Whilst I remain'd above, it seem'd to me that there was Carnal Copulation acted; and that now, Sir Oliver; and then another shape embrac'd you by turns in such immodest manner, as forc'd my Integrity to exclaim against▪

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: This is strange; my Pear-tree inchanted, and I never heard of it before—Come, get me a Ladder, I'll see what Demon of the Dark inhabits there. This must be some Liquorish Devil that loves fruit; and I'll Conjure him I warrant you. Come, bring the Ladder, I say, I'll try what Miracles are here.

div.stage: Dash brings a Ladder; he gets up.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Take away the Ladder now, Dash, whilst I give the sign—

div.stage: He take the Ladder, and she waves her Handkerch.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Carnal Copulation▪ I'd fain see e're a Devil of 'em all pretend Copulation with my Wife—hah.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Charles, who runs and embraces her.
sp.p: Now, who's that? 'dsheart the Colonel, and Kissing her, and she Clasping him—Why, Villain, Traytor, why Wife, Strumpet, you leud Buttock, you. What, this before my face?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, you rail in vain; you know the Pear-tree is inchanted.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: A pox upon you, what still cling'd? still lockt together? why Colonel, Goat, Stallion, how eagerly the strong-backt Dog gripes her? Why you Jade you; no shame! no continency! Bring me the Ladder, Dash—Pimp, Rogue, bring the Ladder, I say—How now, Sirrah; what, must you have a touch too? Here's rare Rampant-doings; but I'll be with you presently.

div.stage: Kingl. leaves her, and Dash steps in and kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: This is such a Master-piece of Wit, that I shall for ever admire thee for.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Go—go in now, and leave the rest to me; but be ready half an hour hence for the third and last experiment.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I'll not lose the pleasure on't for a Million.

div.stage: Old. gets down as far as he can, and tumbles down the rest.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: An t' please your Honour, I was just bringing the Ladder.
sp.stage: Old. rushes on him, throws him down.
sp.p: I profess that was very unchristian-like done.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Where? where is this Monster? This Stallion, Kinglove; ha—I'll firk him, faith.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Kinglove, what d'ye mean, Sir? are you mad?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: No Strumpet, no Buttock, no.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I say you are, if you talk of Kinglove's being here, where no living creature has bin but David there and I.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord; why wilt thou? canst thou? darst thou affirm this to my face? hah? Oh thou incomprehensible—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To your face▪ yes, and prove it too: Were you not told before, that the Devil was in the Pear-tree? But I'll be slander'd no more about it, for I'll have it instantly fell'd, if I live.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: No, Gentlewoman, the Devil was under the Pear-tree, not in it; what, shall I not believe my eyes? was not Kinglove here? did not I see him?

lg.l: How, dear Sir Oliver! what believe your eyes
Before the Wife that in your bosom lyes?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: On my Integrity here has bin no one but her Honour and my self.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Your integrity, Rogue! why Sirrah, did not you too come in for a snack? did not I see you kiss and gripe her by the hand—you letcherous Dog?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir; Alas, Sir,—I profess I have not touched any part of Womans flesh this seven years.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Why then the Devil is there indeed; and I was inchanted too; for I'll be sworn, I think I saw all this; I'll vow, I think I saw kissing, and fumbling, and towzing, and rowzing; but if I am mistaken, I beg your pardon: but the Devil's in the Pear-tree; and as thou say'st, Soul, I'll have it fell'd immediately.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But could you think I could be so wanton, and to Kinglove too above all men?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ay, to him too, above all men. No, no, I see I must be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: He that you shall now know, I have most occasion to hate; for no longer than this morning I receiv'd a Letter from him.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: A Letter! rare stuff in't I warrant.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh, most delicious Lines; which I committed to the fire as soon as read. But the insolent Contents were, He desir'd me in Recompence of the injuries you had done him, to contrive, that by the way of frolick he might have three fillups at your Nose.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: An Impudent Dog, three fillups at my Nose!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ay, and this I was to contrive by a Trick; but that you now may see the unalter'd Candor of your Wife, and know the value of the Jewel you posses; take but my counsel, and wee'l turn this frolick of his a better way.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: With all my heart, faith: A Son of a Whore, three fillups at my Nose! Come, let's about it, I'll take thy counsel to a scruple: A Dog, three fillups at my Nose!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I have long attended the zealous, but have grown poor upon't; but truly do now intend, instead of Preaching, to follow Pimping. I plainly perceive it is the more thriving profession.

sp.speaker: Either.
