sp.p: Now dearest Madam, I may boldly call you mine, since Marriage hath confirm'd it: Oh that the night were come, that I might take possession.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Not to night, let me beg you, Sir: Come, you must deny me nothing, therefore give my modesty this satisfaction: To morrow use your pleasure, because I would not have my Uncle know of our Marriage yet—Take this Key of my Chamber, and be sure to come as private as you can: But not to night, Sir Paul, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p:
Oh, Madam, I am impatient; I rage; I am as wild as an inclos'd Stag in rutting-time. But come, since you will have it so, I'll
try what I can do, and pass this night away with dreaming of to morrow.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Do, and I will of you too, and lie and hug my Pillow as if it were my Husband.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Poor heart! Well, till then farewell. To pass away the time, I'll go and see that Rascal Ionas, who I hear is accus'd for Perjury.

lg.l: So great a Villain could expect no less. Well, adieu.
Be you but kind, and I will still be true.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Ay, go, poor innocent Fool, and I'll be with thee by and by for all this; for I can no more have patience to lye alone, and gnaw the sheets to night, than a young Wife can the next Month after her lying in: This key she says opens her Chamber. Silly Rogue, to design to lye alone, and yet give me the key to come to her: But I know she only deny'd, because she was asham'd to consent so soon; and now I have this key.—I'll surprize her; steal into bed, and give satisfaction to her modesty the right way.—

div.stage: Enter two or three Committee-men, Constable and Rabble, bringing in Jonas, Coppyhold, Slouch and Phebe as to Tryal.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Make room: Keep off there: Clear the way.

sp.speaker: 1 Commit.
sp.p: Officer, look to your Prisoner; he's accus'd of several notorious Crimes, therefore take care of him.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: This is your way of thriving with a pox t'ye, is it? Ah, would my hands were at liberty that I might batter thee a little.

sp.speaker: Cop.
sp.p: Peace, incorrigible Asse, I have known others thrive by it, and so might I—had I not coupled with such a Hound as thou: But the ill Weeds ever spoil the good Corn; and when the Eagle condescends to mix with Crows and Daws, Ruine is inevitable, and Desolation is near.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: If you confess any thing, you are damn'd: Therefore take care, remember you have taken an Oath.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: A precious Rogue—He little thinks I hear him now.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: I care not; you made me take it against my Conscience, and therefore for my part I'll confess all.

sp.speaker: Cop.
sp.p: We are not the first that have broke an Oath upon a good account; therefore hold your self contented.

sp.speaker: 1 Commit.
sp.p: Take away those Fellows, and that Woman, and let 'em be all Whipt soundly: Away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Slouch.
sp.p: So, what think you of Swearing now, Rogue, hah?

sp.speaker: Cop.
sp.p: E'en as well as thou think'st of hanging; which I hope will befall thee e're long for presuming to keep me company; for on my Conscience 'tis that Villainous look of thine hath brought me to this: I am sure I was design'd by Nature for better Fortune.

sp.speaker: 1 Commit.
sp.p: Come, Captain, discharge your Conscience of this great weight. Confess.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: Ay, Captain; Come, confess; are not you a Rascal as one may say?

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Sir, no man can boast of good Principles; therefore every man's a Rascal, and you consequently as well as my self.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: But I am not such a Rascal to hire people to swear a Rape against a Gentleman, that in my Conscience I knew to be innocent: I am not such a Rascal good Domine Ionus.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: But you are such a Rascal to take Bribes on both sides, and especially against the Gentleman you knew to be so innocent: You are such a Rascal, good Justice Eitherside.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: A Damn'd cunning Dog this is: but hang't, nothing he says will be believ'd now; therefore—I am secure enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Commit.
sp.p: However, Captain, you cannot deny but you were found in bed with a Whore: you know this is positively sworn against you.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Heav'n forgive 'em for't; I wish my Innocence be no plague hereafter to their Consciences: 'Tis true (Lodging in the house) I might give the young Woman an Exhortation or so.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: A pox o' your Exhortations; they are very feeling ones to that sex.

sp.speaker: 1 Commit.
sp.p: Nor you never sought to corrupt Sir Charles when he was confin'd, nor these two Fellows and the Girl, and afterwards hired 'em to swear notorious Crimes against the other Witnesses to invalidate their Evidence against you: Nor you never gave 'em the Sacrament in Lambs-Wool and Plumb-Cake to be secret, did you?

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Commit.
sp.p: Make way there: Officer, take care of your Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Well, I thank Heav'n, I obey cheerfully; and will only speak one word before I go, that I may be charitable: Therefore good people, what ever you think of me, I believe you to be good people; very good people; as good Subjects; as true to th' King and Kingly Prerogative; as unwilling to Rebell and Mutiny; and as heartily Conscientious in your dealings as my self. And so farewell t'ye.

div.head: SCENE. Aurelia's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p:
I have gone through all the Rooms, and found not so much as a Cat-stirring; so that I need not fear being discover'd—Ugh, ugh, she's gone to bed already I see—She was resolv'd to make a long lone night on't since 'twas to be her last, for I think 'tis hardly Sun set. Come
now, I'll softly pull off my Clothes—steal in to her, and get her fast in my arms before she wakes—Let's see which side does she lye on. Peeps in. Oh, the Devil, what's here? two Heads in the Bed, and one of 'em a man's head with a Cap on? Oh Jilt, Whore, Traitress—Is this her modesty, with a pox to her? Ay, 'tis so; here are a pair of Breeches too. 'Sdslife I'll kill 'em both. But hold there, I shall injure my self: A pox on 'em, the Devils sleep as if they had bin doing no harm in 'em at all; but I suppose they have taken a receipt for sleep. Well, I'll instantly fetch the Constable and seize 'em: get her portion by Law, then turn her out of doors to her Rascal—whose Breeches here I seize to disable him from denying it, and which I will show to all her friends as the leud Trophies of her dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come, Sir, sit down here, and counterfeit your self asleep; and if he gives you a slight blow or two, have patience, and bear it, that you may have some time to hear his insolent talk.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Is the Rascal come then?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: He's hid in the Alcove in the next room: Sit still, and I'll go fetch him; it may be to humour the Jest, I may at first say as he does, and rail at you, but have patience and wink till I give the sign, and then wee'l hamper him.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: A plaguey cunning Baggage this; I have suspected her ever since the business of the Pear-tree; but now I'll watch her narrowly; I am resolv'd she shall put no trick upon me now, though the Devil himself give her assistance. Here they come.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: This is a tryal of thy Wit indeed, for I thought the business almost impossible.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, there's few of you Men know how far a Womans Wit extends. See, yonder he sits—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—I shall never contain my self, I must laugh.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You may, and speak any thing. Come, let's go to him—you shall hear me begin—who could endure, Sir, to lye by such a Lump as this? such a heavy, dull, insipid Animal, one that's as old at Forty, as another man at Fourscore—One that has the unnatural Gout perpetually, and had a Breath would have bred the Plague, had I not pull'd out two of his Teeth t'other day.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ay, a pox take you for't, I say—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, an over-worn decrepid Rascal, that I believe has not bin a man this 20 years.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Heav'n knows whether he has or no; I am sure he would never let me know it.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Very well, Buttock, very well.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: But as a Revenge for some certain wrongs lately done me, take, Sir, this swinging blow o'th' face—
And, Madam, to compleat it, take you this Kiss: The truest Friend of Love.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: So, so, so—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And not to be behind hand, Sir, take that from me.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: From her too? Very good.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: And that and that—and that for a farewell, my good state Caterpiller—Ha, ha, ha. So now I think 'tis time to go, lest he grow out of patience and hinder me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: He dares not look up till I give the sign; till then we are secure.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: The Jade designs to get him away, I see by their standing so near the door,—But I'll prevent it—

div.stage: Rises up and goes behind Kinglove.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: This dear embrace then, and so adieu.
sp.stage: Whilst Kinglove embraces her, Oldcutt takes off his Girdle and Buckles 'em hoth in.
sp.p: For though thou hast perform'd thy difficult promise, and therein shown thy true and passionate Love; yet such is my hard fortune, that being now oblig'd by the rigorous Laws of gratitude and honour, I never must agen perform this kindness.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O yes, yes; many, many times embrace your fill: I think you are close enough now.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hah—Hell and the Devil, what's this?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Hey, who's within there? Call all my Servants, my Coachman, Footman, and Groom and my Gardiner, Cook, Postilion and Butler. Carry the news about the Town, that I, Mr. Chairman, am a Cuckold; A Cuckold, a notorious Cuckold.

div.stage: Enter Eitherside with the Breeches mounted on a Staff, Heartall in a Gown, Aurelia, Dash, Constable and Officers.

sp.speaker: Either.
sp.p: A Cuckold, a Cuckold; who dares talk of a Cuckold before my face, that am Commander in chief? Witness my Standard here: I am the head of the horned Flock, and bear the Bell before all the Cuckolds in the Town.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: What, more Roguery still? How now, Sir Paul, what's the matter, Sir Paul? 'Tis the very Eclipse of the Moon sure? And there's a General Cuckoldom in nature.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Why you must know, Sir, that being led by an oblique, or rather inevitable destiny to perpetrate Acts of Ignominy to my self: I chanc'd to Correspond, Convene or enter into a League of Conjugal Quality with your Neice Aurelia there. But a pox on Tropes and Figures in such a Cause as this: In short, Sir, I have this afternoon marry'd her; am already abus'd, and a Cuckold in Folio.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Give me thy hand: not a word more on't: 'Tis the fashion I am a Cuckold too.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: What I have done, Sir, the Law shall answer; I hope, Sir, you'll require no other satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: No, Sir, no, I know you are for tilting; but I know a better way than so, I thank you; I'll bring Cook and Littleton to Fence with you, Sir; I'll firk you like a Tory as you are.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: For my part I'll shut my self into my Closet, and never see the Face of man agen.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Ay, you may go, Madam: But as for your Money—I'll take care of that: Sir Oliver, I hope you'll see this 5000 l. paid.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Five thousand pound! for what, Boy?

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: For what? for your Neice's portion: Nay, 'Gad the Law shall firk you too, if you grow refractory.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Sir, she is not worth five groats; I have kept her this seven year upon Charity: And now I think on't, there's a hundred pound due to me for Dyet and Necessaries. This must be paid, Sir, or the Law shall firk you if you go to that.

sp.speaker: Eith.
sp.p: Well, I see 'tis in vain to resist ill luck: The Devil did owe me an ill turn, and he has paid it me with a vengeance: Therefore honest Sir Paul, you must have patience, and bear your afflictions like a man.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: For you, Madam, you must e'en be sent packing after your Neice, and, Officers, seize on that Ruffian there: I'll teach you, Sir, to make a Cuckold of a Politician.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You cannot send me into worse company than your own, where ever it is.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Sir, your Malice to me is as ridiculous as your Jest: But for her sake I'll give you the satisfaction, to tell you, that upon my Honour, and by all that's Sacred, she's truly vertuous, though I would have reveng'd my self upon thee, I must confess; for I did design to get a Royalist upon thy Wife, that should have liv'd to pull thee by the Nose.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Very well, Tory, very well: Hold him fast, Officers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Officers, I command you in the Protector's Name to discharge him. Sir Oliver, you are hereby also Commanded to re-deliver to this Noble Gentleman all his Sequestred Lands.
And further, Sir, the Protector bid me tell you he had heard so large a Character of your Fidelity and Vertue, that he would at any rate buy your Friendship.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Sir, for my Estate I thank him: but for my Service and Loyal Allegiance, they are Sacred to my Prince, and shall continue so.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Bravely resolv'd, Sir, though I could wish you of our side.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Now I am resolv'd to hang my self; for I'd as leive lose my life as my estate: A pox on Power, I say: A man can never thrive in an Age
where there is another Rogue that's of greater Quality than himself.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: And now my fairest Love, wee'l both be happy.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: D'ye not forget me then?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Believe I never can: See, Gentlemen, another wonder here this suppos'd youth. Companion of my Troubles, he that was charg'd by Villians for committing a Rape, is a Woman.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: 'Tis wonderfull!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: And shall within these few hours be my Wife—hah.
Lieutenant, thou art come happily to be a Guest too; hast thou heard the News? My Estate is surrendred back, and all's as well as ever.

sp.speaker: Broom.
sp.p: The Protector's very sick, and I suppose has done you this good office, only as a greater help to his Salvation. Besides, there's a great Rumour that the times will change.

lg.l: Let 'em: They are not then like me.
That like a Rock have stood the Storms of State,
As well as Calms, and yet would never change.
My Actions still in this Plebeian Age,
Grounded on Justice, Honesty and Honour,
Shall teach the Erring Natives to be Loyal:
My Tongue ne'r rail at Governments or Laws,
Nor my Sword wound but in the Royal Cause.
T' obey my Prince shall be my greatest Care,
Whom Heav'n preserve secure as Angels are;
And to summ up all Blessings in a Pray'r,
Good Heav'n, that dost the Fate of Kings foresee,
Save and defend Great England's Monarchy.
WHat in my face cou'd this strange Scribler see,
(Uds Heart) to make an Evidence of me?
That never cou'd agree with Ignoramus,
But for a Tender Conscience have been famous.
For who are these among you here that have
Not in your Rambles heard of Tory Cave;
That rores in Coffee-house, and wasts his Wealth,
Toping the Gentleman in Scotland's Health.
This part should have been given some hardy Fool,
That had more sense for Int'rest than his Soul.
I never had the knack of Truth-denying,
Loving Sedition, Loyalty defying;
Nor could I take Ten Pound a week for Lying.
But since 'tis so, I must intreat the pity
Of you our (never-failing) Friends i'th' City.
For though I was not e're brought up to th' Trade,
Like Setting-Dog I may with Art be made.
In time such wholsome Documents receive:
Uds Zooks, who knows but I may stand for Shrieve?
And faith, that thought hath rowz'd up my ambition:
Well, Sirs, give me but House-room, and Provision;
Cry up the Play, and always let me find
My Benefactors Bountifull and Kind;
Then, if you want a Swinger at a word,
'Zounds I'll swear for you through a two-inch-Board.
